title: One in five Australians wash hands after visiting bathroom, says Food Safety Information Council
text:
More than one in five Australians don't wash their hands after going to the toilet according to startling statistics.

The Food Safety Information Council (FSIC) released the figures on Wednesday, which showed men were the worst offenders.

Only 76 per cent of men washed their hands after visiting the bathroom compared to 86 per cent of women.

‘Good handwashing, using running water, soap and drying hands thoroughly is a basic public health message that people seem to be forgetting,' FSIC's communication director Lydia Buchtmann said.

More than one in five Australians don't wash their hands after going to the toilet according to startling statistics (stock image)

'This behaviour could be contributing to the estimated 4.1million cases of food poisoning each year not to mention spreading viral infections such as cold, influenza and norovirus. ’

Their sense of food hygiene was even poorer with only 59 per cent washing their hands before handling food - meanwhile 66 per cent of women followed good hygiene practice.

When should you wash and dry your hands While hand washing and good hygiene may be general knowledge, not everybody seems to be making the connection. The Food Safety Information Council has given a brief list of when people should be washing and drying their hands: 1) Before handling, preparing and eating food 2) After touching raw meat, fish, shell eggs or poultry 3) After using the toilet, attending to children’s (or others) toiletting and changing nappies 4) After blowing your nose 5) After touching a pet 6) After gardening

Young people were also less likely to wash their hands after visiting the bathroom compared to older people.

Only 69 per cent of people under the age of 34 followed good hygiene practice while 86 per cent of people over 50 washed their hands.

The same trend was seen food preparation, with only 59 per cent of young people washing their hands before handling food compared to 63 per cent of older people.

'Poor handwashing knowledge among young people is also a concern as they often become professional food handlers,' Ms Buchtmann said.

The FSIC recommended people to wash and dry their hands in at least six different scenarios: before handling food, after touching raw meat and after touching a pet, to name a few.

The council even gave a breakdown of how people should be washing their hands.

People should wet and rub their hands together to build up a good lather of soap, rinse them under water and dry them on a clean towel for at least 20 seconds.

Touching a surface with wet hands could facilitate the spread of germs.
